item.content:
Links

Easy use of Markdown. To display a link, the plaintext in *.md 

[Google](https://www.google.com/)
renders as
Google

TeX

Can't use .md, use .mmark as extension of document. Add to header of *.mmark markup = mmark. Add to bottom of footer.html (which is loaded on every page) 

<script src="//yihui.name/js/math-code.js"></script>
<script async
  src="//mathjax.rstudio.com/latest/MathJax.js?config=TeX-MML-AM_CHTML">
</script>
This uses MathJax, but it might be worthwhile to swap to KaTeX for faster rendering.

Math Mode

To display Math Mode TeX, the plaintext in *.mmark

`\[ \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{E} = \frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_0} \]`
`\[ \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{B} = 0 \]`
`\[ \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{E} = - \frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \]`
`\[ \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{B} = \frac{1}{c^2} \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t} \]`

renders as \[ \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{E} = \frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_0} \] \[ \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{B} = 0 \] \[ \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{E} = - \frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \] \[ \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{B} = \frac{1}{c^2} \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t} \]

In-Line

To display in-line TeX, the plaintext in *.mmark 

textleft `\( \det(\lambda I - \textbf{A}) = 0\)` textright
renders as
textleft \( \det(\lambda I - \textbf{A}) = 0\) textright

Images

Images are accessed from the ./static/ directory. It seems better organized to make a subdirectory with the title, so in this case within ./static/post-images/template is an image EMWave.png. GIFs use the same format, so equivalently use GIF EMWave.gif. 

![Image Text](/post-images/template/EMWave.png)
renders as

Embedded YouTube videos

For a YouTube video URL https://youtu.be/rB83DpBJQsE, use the video ID (rB83DpBJQsE) and youtube.com/embed to make an embedded YouTube player. If just using an iframe, the video looks fine on desktop, but exceeds the text for small widths. To fix this, the size of the embedded video changes. This uses CSS, so in config.toml add customCSS = ["css/videos.css"], where the file videos.css contains 

.video-container {
  position: relative;
  padding-bottom: 56.25%;
  padding-top: 30px; height: 0; overflow: hidden;
}

.video-container iframe,
.video-container object,
.video-container embed {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
}
This adds the CSS necessary, so 
<div class="video-container">
<iframe width="853" height="480" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/rB83DpBJQsE"
  allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"
  frameborder="0"
  allowfullscreen>
</iframe>
</div>
renders as
I've found a good way to test this, rather than just open on both mobile and desktop, is to open Chrome's developer tools and drag the window to different widths.
